title: rtorrent: Kernel panic on high traffic

sentences.text: I am using rTorrent on my server, i have an 100Mbps line, and when bittorrent traffic goes up to 7-8MB/s, my memory gets filled to 100% and in a matter of seconds i get a kernel panic.
Here is the dmesg dump captured via netconsole.
[ 1297.939815] Pid: 0, comm: swapper Tainted: G   M       2.6.32-5-686 #1

Versions of packages rtorrent depends on:
ii  libc6                   2.11.2-10        Embedded GNU C Library: Shared lib
ii  libcurl3                7.21.0-2         Multi-protocol file transfer libra ii  libgcc1                 1:4.4.5-8        GCC support library
ii  libncursesw5            5.7+20100313-5   shared libraries for terminal hand ii  libsigc++-2.0-0c2a      2.2.4.2-1        type-safe Signal Framework for C++
ii  libstdc++6              4.4.5-8          The GNU Standard C++ Library v3

ii  libxmlrpc-c3            1.06.27-1.1      A lightweight RPC library based on
ii  screen                        4.0.3-14   terminal multiplexor with VT100/AN
On Wed, Oct 12, 2011 at 04:58, Andrei Popescu <pope.xtream@gmail.com> wrote:
> I am using rTorrent on my server, i have an 100Mbps line, and when bittorrent traffic goes up to 7-8MB/s, my memory gets filled to 100% and in a matter of seconds i get a kernel panic.
> Here is the dmesg dump captured via netconsole.
> [ 1297.939815] Pid: 0, comm: swapper Tainted: G  M    2.6.32-5-686 #1
It is quite bad that rtorrent causes your machine to have a kernel panic.
OTOH, the kernel should never let userspace applications do that.
Are you sure that your machine is OK?
The taint flag M indicates a Machine Check Exception...
Can you stress test the machine in question to rule out hardware causes?
I stress tested the machine using stress.
Here is my output from stress, and the load average after about 3 minutes of running stress
stress: info: [8967] dispatching hogs: 8 cpu, 8 io, 8 vm, 8 hdd
stress: dbug: [8967] using backoff sleep of 96000us

stress: dbug: [8970] touching bytes in strides of 4096 bytes ...
stress: dbug: [8999] opened ./stress.HhUSDr for writing 1073741824 bytes
stress: dbug: [8987] opened ./stress.XfbOeu for writing 1073741824 bytes

stress: dbug: [8979] opened ./stress.taNxyx for writing 1073741824 bytes
stress: dbug: [8971] opened ./stress.11Jpjz for writing 1073741824 bytes
Even at this huge load average the machine didn't crash
Also i ran memtest86+, 2 complete passes, no errors
Usually with rTorrent the machine crashes in a matter of seconds.
My Internet connection is an 100Mbps Download/100Mbps Upload [maximum values],
so the download/upload speeds get up really fast to about 7-8MB/s.
Now i compiled xmlrpc-c, libtorrent, rtorrent from source
I used xmlrpc-c latest SVN trunk, libtorrent-0.12.9, rtorrent-0.8.9.
those after a system reboot and limiting rtorrent's memory usage to 400MB, the server is running fine for about 4 hours
I think there is bug related to memory allocation which happens to my machine when i have several hundreds of TCP connections and high network traffic
> On Wed, Oct 12, 2011 at 04:58, Andrei Popescu <pope.xtream@gmail.com>
> > I am using rTorrent on my server, i have an 100Mbps line, and when
> bittorrent traffic goes up to 7-8MB/s, my memory gets filled to 100% and in > a matter of seconds i get a kernel panic.
> > Here is the dmesg dump captured via netconsole.
> > [ 1297.939815] Pid: 0, comm: swapper Tainted: G   M       2.6.32-5-686 #1
> It is quite bad that rtorrent causes your machine to have a kernel > panic.
OTOH, the kernel should never let userspace applications do > that.
> Are you sure that your machine is OK?
The taint flag M indicates a > Machine Check Exception...
Can you stress test the machine in question > to rule out hardware causes?
> Now i compiled xmlrpc-c, libtorrent, rtorrent from source
> I used xmlrpc-c latest SVN trunk, libtorrent-0.12.9, rtorrent-0.8.9.
> those after a system reboot and limiting rtorrent's memory usage to 400MB, > the server is running fine for about 4 hours
Now that 0.8.9 is in testing, have you tried it?
Does that version work for you, or only your custom build?
After more tuning, i was able to install and run the version in the Repositories.
I've added more RAM to the machine, changed the cpu to a new one, attached a 750GB SATA Hard Disk drive and it is running fine @ 11.5 MB/s Download and about 10MB/s Upload.
> > Now i compiled xmlrpc-c, libtorrent, rtorrent from source
> > I used xmlrpc-c latest SVN trunk, libtorrent-0.12.9, rtorrent-0.8.9.
> > those after a system reboot and limiting rtorrent's memory usage to > 400MB,
> > the server is running fine for about 4 hours
> Now that 0.8.9 is in testing, have you tried it?
Does that version work > for you, or only your custom build?
> After more tuning, i was able to install and run the version in the > Repositories.
I've added more RAM to the machine, changed the cpu to a new > one, attached a 750GB SATA Hard Disk drive and it is running fine @ 11.5
Since it's working for you now, and no one else confirmed the issue, I'm closing this bug now.
